title-group.article-title: Preparation and characterization of antibacterial poly(vinylidene fluoride)-silver composites

contrib-group.aff: Department of Breast Oncology, Cancer Institute and Hospital of Tianjin Medical University, Hexi District, Tianjin, China

author-notes.corresp: Xiaochuan Tang, Department of Breast Oncology, Cancer Institute and Hospital of Tianjin Medical University, Hexi District, Tianjin, 300060, China Email: xctang111@gmail.com

abstract.p: Poly(vinylidene fluoride)-silver (PVDF-Ag) composite films were synthesized by in situ reduction of silver nitrate using N, N-dimethylformamide as solvent and reductant simultaneously. The effects of silver on the thermal property and crystal structure of PVDF were characterized using differential scanning calorimetry and X-ray diffraction. The mechanical properties and morphology of the composite membrane were characterized using a material testing machine and scanning electron microscopy. The toughness of the composite film was proved to increase sharply by adding 10% silver nitrate. The composite films were verified to be effective to kill Escherichia coli.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Polymer composites containing metal particles have triggered much attention in materials science for their potential application in catalysis, electrochemistry, separation, and biomaterials. Poly(vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF), as a semicrystalline polymer, is widely used as substrates for polymer composites because of its high strength, good thermal stability and good resistance to solvents, acids, and bases. PVDF composites 1–5 including PVDF/Ag, PVDF/SiO2, PVDF/TiO2, PVDF/heteropoly acids (HPA), and PVDF/polyurethane (PU) blends have been prepared by research groups for various uses.

The utilization of silver as an antibacterial agent 6
–9 in water treatment and textiles has been studied for decades. Its dominant antibacterial activity is known to be efficient against nearly 650 types of bacteria. A low concentration of silver nitrate was reported to be lethal to a range of microbial species, both Gram-positive and Gram-negative. 10 Silver ions are very effective as antibacterial agents in killing bacteria. However, it readily produces side-effects on health. Compared to silver ions, the antibacterial effect of bulk silver is long term and stable. However, it is difficult to apply widely in industry or daily life because of its high price and low ion release rate. Recently, the application of silver nanoparticles has opened a new door for silver as an antibacterial agent. In comparison with silver ions, silver nanoparticles are long lasting, control releasable and low cost, with a high release rate of silver ions. 11 Therefore, nanoparticles are expected to play a crucial role in the food industry, water disinfection, and other situations related to disinfection. 12

Many methods have been used to prepare polymer–silver composites. Maja Radetic et al. 13 have prepared antibacterial fiber using a surface coating of silver nanoparticles on the corona-treated polyamide fibers. Park et al. 14 has prepared nanofibers using electrospinning of a mixture solution of nylon 6 and silver nanoparticles. Compton et al. 15 have obtained a PVDF–silver composite film with uniform distribution of silver particles by annealing PVDF film with a precursor silver salt at high temperature. However, in the present study, a PVDF-Ag composite film was prepared by in-situ reduction of silver nitrate using N, N-dimethylformamide as solvent and reductant simultaneously.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: Poly(vinylidene fluoride) (Solef_PVDF 6010) was received from SOLVAY China Co. N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF) and silver nitrate (AgNO3) were purchased from Keruisi Chemical, China. All chemicals were purchased and used without further purification. Deionized water was obtained using an RO filtration system.

sec.title: Preparation of PVDF-Ag composite films
sec.p: Homogenous solutions containing various amounts of PVDF (15, 20, and 25 wt.%) and different amounts of silver nitrate (1, 5 and 10 wt.%) were prepared using DMF as solvent at room temperature. The solutions changed from transparent to dark yellow after aging for 20 h at 60°C with stirring, which means the formation of silver nanoparticles via in-situ reduction of silver nitrate by DMF.

Then the solutions were stood aside for another 5 h and a film was made on the glass plate by scraping the solutions using a doctor’s blade. The film was peeled off after immersing the glass plate in pure water for a phase inversion process, and then dried in vacuum oven at 60°C. The final composite films were called PVDFx-Agy, where x denotes the weight percentage of PVDF and y denotes that of silver nitrate (e.g. PVDF20-Ag10). A pure PVDF film without Ag nanoparticles called PVDF20 was also prepared using a similar method without adding silver nitrate.

sec.title: Characterization of PVDF-Ag composite films
sec.p: Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) was acquired on a PERKIN ELMER DSC7 at a heating rate of 10°C min−1 and temperature range of room temperature to 200°C. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern was recorded at room temperature using Cu radiation, on a Bruker AXS-made powder diffractometer D8 DISCOVER. The mechanical properties were studied using a material testing machine (YG605). All samples were cut to 4 cm × 1 cm before drawing at a speed of 20 mm min−1. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were examined using a JSM-6700F after coating with a thin film of gold using a sprayer.

sec.title: Antibacterial activity test of the composite films
sec.p: The antibacterial activity test of the composite films was carried out using an agar disk diffusion method. A bacterial suspension of Escherichia coli was diluted to 104–105 cfu mL−1 in deionized pure water. Nutrient agar was poured onto disposable sterilized Petri dishes and was allowed to solidify before 100 µL of the bacterial suspension was splashed over the dish and was spread uniformly. A piece of film, 2 cm × 2 cm, was gently covered over the solidified agar. Dishes were incubated at 37°C for 24 h. Digital images were taken to vividly show the antibacterial activity of the composite films.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: Figure 1 shows the thermal properties of the composite films. The peaks at 170°C were attributed to the melting temperature of PVDF crystals as appeared in all samples. However, additional attention was given to the peaks around 200–300°C, which is due to the disentanglement of the PVDF main chains. As the concentration of PVDF in the precursor solution was increased from 15 to 25%, the disentanglement peaks shifted to higher temperatures, namely from 200 to 245°C as shown in Figure 1(a). With the same PVDF concentration, the amount of silver nitrate in the precursor solution was varied and the disentanglement peaks were also very different. When 1% silver nitrate was added the disentanglement peaks changed from 195 to 230°C. As the silver nitrate content was increased to 10%, the disentanglement peak was lowered a little and an enhanced heat flow was seen at 285°C; this probably came from the strong interaction between PVDF molecular chains and silver.

Adding silver to the composites also had an effect on the crystal phase of PVDF apart for the entanglement states. As shown in Figure 2, PVDF concentration had no influence on the XRD pattern (Figure 2(a)). However, the crystal structures of PVDF20 and PVDF20-Ag10 were very different (Figure 2(b)). When 10% silver nitrate was added, the α phase crystals with trans-gauche-trans-gauche (TGTG) alignment showed that the peaks at 2θ = 18.4 (0 2 0) and 26.5 (0 2 1) increased. This increase in intensity of the α phase crystals was attributed to the interaction of silver with the dipole fluorine atoms at the all trans structure of PVDF, thereby forming more α phase crystals. Ozkazanc et al. 16 reported that in barium chloride-filled PVDF films, the barium chloride formed fluorine bridges over the chain segments on the crystal lamellar surface, which increased the total degree of crystallinity. Dong et al. 17 also reported that in a PVDF/silver nanocomposite, the polymer exited in the α form with TGTG conformation.

The mechanical properties of PVDF-Ag composite films was recorded as shown in Figure 3. Increasing the concentration of PVDF definitely enhanced the strain and stress of the composites (Figure 3(a)). One reason for this augmentation in the mechanical properties is the formation of more entanglement points in the composite films prepared using higher concentrations of PVDF, which also was verified by the DSC results. Another reason that can be attributed to the structure of the composite films is shown in Figure 4. As the concentration increased, the crystals of PVDF became smaller and denser in packing. More obviously an augmentation in the mechanical properties was observed by adding 10% silver nitrate to the composite film (Figure 3(b)). The broken load (from 1 to 7 cN) and stress length (from 2.5 to 5 mm) were turned into seven and two times, respectively, by adding 10% silver nitrate, in comparison with the pure PVDF film. This change was observed from two aspects: first, the polymer crystals were formed more in the α phase; and second, compact structures (see Figure 5) were formed due to the decrease in crystallinity (as confirmed by the decrease in melting enthalpy as shown in Figure 1) and the delaying action of silver on PVDF crystallization (the crystals linking together and becoming continuous structures).

caption.p: Mechanical properties of PVDF-Ag composite films.
SEM images of PVDF-Ag composite films with 5%Ag and (a) 15%PVDF, (b) 20%PVDF, (c) 25%PVDF: scale bar 1 µm.
SEM images of PVDF-Ag composite films with 20% PVDF and (a) 0%Ag, (b) 1%Ag, (c) 10%Ag: scale bar 2 µm.

sec.p: The antibacterial activity of the composite films was tested following the procedure described in the section entitled ‘Characterization of PVDF-Ag composite films’. It was found that, in the PVDF/Ag composite films (shown in Figure 6(b) and (c)) the growth was much reduced, whereas in the case of pure PVDF film (shown in Figure 6(a)) the growth was still active, which confirmed the antibacterial activity of the PVDF-Ag composite films. Moreover, the bacterial colony in the dishes with the PVDF-Ag composite films were much smaller than that of pure PVDF film; this may be due to the diffusion of silver ions from the film to the nutrient agar. Yuan et al. 18 prepared antibacterial PVDF-silver nanofiber using electrospinning. The nanofibers have good antibacterial activity, although preparation of the nanofiber needs a special electrospinning device. Grafting of polymer-containing dimethylamino groups on the PVDF membrane surface was reported. 19 The membrane could remove the Gram-negative bacterium and inhibited bacterial reproduction. However, the method described is really complicated in comparison with the one used in the present study by in-situ reduction of silver salt.

caption.p: Photos of nutrient agar treated with E. coli using composite films with 20% PVDF and (a) 0%Ag, (b) 1%Ag, (c) 10%Ag.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: PVDF-silver composite films with antibacterial activity were prepared by an in-situ reduction method. The composite films were found to be increasingly entangled as silver was added and there were more α phase PVDF crystals. The structures of the composite films became denser and the mechanical properties was enhanced by adding 10% silver nitrate to the system.
